assessment.title: Adivirtus AI Onboarding Assessment
assessment.description: This comprehensive assessment analyzes your unique learning preferences, cognitive patterns, and skill acquisition tendencies. Your responses will be used to create a hyper-personalized learning roadmap that aligns with your natural learning style, maximizing efficiency and effectiveness.

questions.prompt: You need to master a new data analysis software for an upcoming project. How would you prefer to learn it?

options.text: I'd prefer a video tutorial with screen recordings showing the interface, with color-coded highlights and visual cues pointing out important features, ideally with diagrams illustrating the workflow.

I'd prefer a live webinar where an expert explains the logic and functionality verbally, with opportunities to ask questions and hear detailed explanations about how different features relate to each other.
I'd prefer a sandbox environment where I can immediately interact with the software, trying different features hands-on while completing guided practice exercises that let me experiment directly.
I'd prefer comprehensive written documentation with step-by-step instructions that I can highlight, annotate, and reference while taking my own detailed notes about the process.

questions.reasoning: This question presents a workplace scenario requiring technical skill acquisition, making it directly relevant to corporate upskilling. Each option clearly distinguishes between visual (screen recording), auditory (verbal explanation), kinesthetic (hands-on practice), and reading/writing (documentation study) modalities in a professional context.

questions.prompt: When developing a new creative skill for a professional project, which approach would be most effective for you?

options.text: Study high-quality visual examples and demonstrations, observe experts performing the skill, and use visual references and mood boards to guide my learning.
Listen to detailed verbal descriptions of techniques and principles, participate in discussion-based learning sessions, and have processes explained verbally with emphasis on key terminology.
Immediately start hands-on practice with guided exercises, learn through physical trial-and-error, and develop muscle memory through repeated practical application.
Begin with written tutorials and theory documents, take detailed notes on techniques and approaches, and follow written step-by-step guides while documenting my progress.

questions.prompt: During a collaborative problem-solving session with unfamiliar colleagues, you typically:

options.text: Take initiative and suggest immediate practical approaches
Observe group dynamics and consider multiple perspectives before speaking
Focus on establishing clear conceptual frameworks for the discussion
Identify real-world constraints and guide solutions toward practical outcomes

questions.prompt: When independently learning a complex subject outside your expertise, you're most likely to:

options.text: Dive into practical exercises to gain hands-on experience quickly
Gather various resources and perspectives before forming conclusions
Seek comprehensive understanding of underlying principles and models
Focus on applications and relevance to your specific goals

questions.prompt: In learning environments, which condition is most essential for your optimal performance?

options.text: Freedom to experiment and make mistakes without judgment or negative consequences
Clear structure with explicit expectations, guidelines, and consistent feedback
Collaborative atmosphere with opportunities for discussion and peer learning
Control over my learning pace and direction with minimal supervision

questions.prompt: You need to memorize important technical specifications and procedures for a certification exam. Which approach would work best for you?

options.text: Convert information into charts, mind maps, and color-coded visual hierarchies, using spatial arrangement and visual symbols to represent relationships between concepts.
Create spoken mnemonics or rhythmic patterns, record yourself explaining key concepts and listen repeatedly, or discuss the material verbally in study groups.
Create physical flashcards that you can manipulate and sort, act out processes physically, or teach the material to someone else using demonstrations and interactive examples.
Create structured written outlines and summaries, rewrite key information in your own words multiple times, and organize information into tables, lists, and definitions.

questions.prompt: In which learning context do you maintain focus and engagement most effectively?

options.text: Short, intensive sessions with frequent breaks
Extended deep-dive sessions with minimal interruption
Varied activities addressing the same topic from different angles
Interactive sessions with immediate application and feedback

questions.prompt: When comparing digital learning resources to traditional methods, you typically find:

options.text: Digital resources with multimedia and interactivity enhance my understanding
Traditional books and written materials lead to deeper comprehension
A combination works best, using different formats for different purposes
Interactive content that requires engagement regardless of medium

questions.prompt: When receiving feedback on your work, which approach helps you improve most effectively?

options.text: Specific examples of what worked well and clear suggestions for changes
Understanding underlying principles behind the feedback
Opportunity to discuss and explore alternatives collaboratively
Immediate chance to apply feedback and retry the task

questions.prompt: Listen to this complex explanation, then select which element helped you understand best:

media.alt: Audio explanation of a complex topic with multiple elements

options.text: The analogies and visual descriptions provided
The logical structure and clear transitions
The practical examples and applications mentioned
The repeated emphasis on key points

questions.presentation: Display an audio player followed by options as radio buttons.

questions.prompt: When your preferred learning method isn't available, how do you typically respond?

options.text: Quickly adapt and find alternative approaches
Experience initial frustration but eventually adjust
Struggle significantly and seek to recreate preferred conditions
Proactively prepare multiple learning strategies in advance

questions.prompt: This interactive assessment measures your information processing speed across different modalities.
questions.presentation: Render the LearningSpeedTest component with visual, auditory, and text-based elements.

questions.prompt: Study this diagram showing different approaches to solving a complex problem. Which pathway most resembles your natural approach?

media.alt: Diagram showing different problem-solving approaches and pathways

options.text: Path A: Break down into components, analyze each part, then synthesize (Analytical)
Path B: Start with known patterns, apply and adjust as needed (Pattern-Based)
Path C: Generate multiple solutions, test and iterate rapidly (Experimental)
Path D: Define ideal outcome, work backward to current state (Goal-Oriented)

questions.presentation: Display the image on top, then render options as radio buttons.

questions.prompt: When applying knowledge from one domain to solve problems in another area, you typically:

options.text: Look for underlying principles that connect both domains
Adapt specific techniques and modify them for the new context
Start fresh in each domain, with minimal crossover
Use analogies and metaphors to bridge different areas

questions.prompt: Describe a specific instance where you struggled to learn something but eventually succeeded. What specific strategies made the difference, and how has this experience affected your approach to learning new things?
questions.presentation: Render as a large text area input.

questions.prompt: During which time of day do you typically learn new skills most effectively?

options.text: Early morning (5am-9am)
Mid-day (10am-2pm)
Afternoon (3pm-7pm)
Evening/Night (8pm-12am)

questions.prompt: What is your optimal duration for focused learning before needing a significant break?

options.text: Short sessions (15-25 minutes)
Medium sessions (30-45 minutes)
Long sessions (1-2 hours)
Extended deep work (2+ hours)

questions.prompt: When learning complex technical concepts, you typically:

options.text: Grasp the big picture quickly, but need time for details
Build understanding incrementally, step by step
Need to experiment and apply concepts to understand them
Require clear examples before abstract explanations

questions.prompt: Which approach helps you most when learning a new skill for your job?

options.text: Understanding how it connects to the broader organizational goals
Seeing exactly how it applies to my daily work tasks
Learning from colleagues who already use this skill effectively
Having time to explore and experiment with the skill independently

questions.prompt: When learning material becomes overwhelming, which strategy works best for you?

options.text: Take a break and return with fresh perspective
Break it down into smaller, manageable components
Seek out alternative explanations or resources
Discuss the material with someone else

questions.prompt: What most motivates you to learn new skills at work?

options.text: Career advancement and new opportunities
Mastery and personal satisfaction from improvement
Recognition from peers and management
Contributing more effectively to team/company goals

questions.prompt: How sensitive are you to distractions while learning?

options.text: Highly sensitive - need complete quiet and focus
Moderately sensitive - can filter minor distractions
Slightly sensitive - only major interruptions affect learning
Minimally affected - can learn effectively in varied environments

questions.prompt: When do you prefer to receive feedback during the learning process?

options.text: Immediately after each step or task
At predetermined checkpoints throughout the process
Only when I request it or encounter difficulties
After completing the entire learning module or project

questions.prompt: How do you typically integrate new information with your existing knowledge?

options.text: Look for connections to what I already know and build bridges
Reorganize my understanding to accommodate new information
Keep new knowledge separate until I fully understand it
Test new information against my existing knowledge for conflicts

questions.prompt: When learning a new technical skill, which pattern typically describes your learning speed over time?

options.text: Strong start with quick fundamentals, then gradual slowing as complexity increases
Steady, consistent pace from beginning to end regardless of complexity
Careful, slower start, then accelerating as concepts connect and make sense
Variable pace that adjusts based on the specific content difficulty

questions.prompt: When estimating how long it will take you to learn a new skill, how accurate are your predictions?

options.text: Highly accurate (within 10% of actual time)
Moderately accurate (within 10-30% of actual time)
Limited accuracy (within 30-50% of actual time)
Difficult to predict (often off by more than 50%)

questions.prompt: How does the speed at which you learn affect your ability to retain that knowledge long-term?

options.text: Quick learning leads to better retention for me
Slower, deliberate learning improves my retention
My learning speed doesn't affect my retention ability
Retention depends on the subject, not my learning speed

questions.prompt: Which factor most significantly improves your learning speed for technical content?

options.text: Clear visual explanations and diagrams
Immediate hands-on practice opportunities
Relating new content to my existing knowledge
Distraction-free environment with focused time

questions.prompt: How do you best determine whether you've successfully learned something?

options.text: Completing defined milestones or objectives
Successfully applying the knowledge in real situations
Ability to clearly explain the concept to someone else
Internal sense of confidence and comfort with the material

questions.prompt: Your learning preferences may vary by subject. When specifically learning MATHEMATICAL concepts, which approach do you most prefer?

options.text: Visual representations of equations, graphs, and visual models to understand mathematical relationships.
Listening to step-by-step verbal explanations of mathematical processes and talking through problems aloud.
Working through many example problems hands-on and using physical manipulatives or interactive simulations.
Reading mathematical theory and writing out detailed solution steps while taking thorough notes.

questions.prompt: Many people learn best through multiple approaches combined. Which combination of learning modes works best for you?

options.text: Visual and Kinesthetic: I learn best with visual demonstrations followed by hands-on practice.
Auditory and Read/Write: I learn best by listening to explanations while taking notes.
Visual and Read/Write: I learn best by reading materials with visual aids and diagrams.
Kinesthetic and Auditory: I learn best through physical activity combined with verbal instructions.

questions.prompt: When using digital learning platforms, which features most enhance your learning experience?

options.text: High-quality visualizations, videos, animations, and visual simulations.
Audio lectures, recorded discussions, and voice explanations with pronunciation guides.
Interactive elements, clickable exercises, drag-and-drop activities, and practice simulations.
Comprehensive text resources, downloadable documents, and note-taking capabilities.

questions.prompt: When solving complex logical problems or troubleshooting issues, how do you prefer to process information?

options.text: Visualize the problem structure using diagrams, flowcharts, or mental imagery to map out solutions.
Talk through the problem verbally, discussing options aloud and hearing different perspectives.
Try different approaches hands-on, testing solutions practically to see what works.
Write down the problem components systematically, listing options and analyzing them in written form.

questions.prompt: Based on your previous learning experiences, which learning style do you believe works best for you overall?

options.text: Visual: I learn best when information is presented visually with images, diagrams, and demonstrations.
Auditory: I learn best when listening to explanations, discussions, and verbal instructions.
Kinesthetic: I learn best through hands-on activities, practice, and physical engagement with materials.
Read/Write: I learn best through reading text and writing notes, summaries, and outlines.
Multimodal: I learn equally well through a combination of different styles depending on the context.

resources.alt: Infographic showing different learning methods with visual, auditory, and kinesthetic elements
Audio explanation of a complex topic with multiple elements
Diagram showing different problem-solving approaches and pathways

resources.description: Interactive component for measuring information processing speed across different modalities

resources.alt: Demonstration of different cognitive load scenarios
resources.description: Open-source video resource for cognitive assessment
